text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Wednesday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- President Ulmanis opened the first meeting of the new cabinet which lasted 5 hours. Prime Minister Guntars Krasts said he hopes this government will be the last one before the next parliamentary election.
- Some 150 people protested near the building of the Riga city council against growing public utility tariffs.
- The cabinet's committee has decided to put off by one week the consideration of the memorandum the Latvian government will send to the European Commission.
- The Riga city council has decided to organise another auction to sell the asphalt plant bought by the previous council.
- A new exhibition hall will be opened in September in the premises of Alfa, a former electronics plant.
- The ministry of finance has announced that on August 14 and 15 it will pay back the 4 billion yen eurobond it issued in 1995.
- A record number of ships, 369, entered the Port of Riga in July. In May, 342 vessels visited the port.
